default.AboutText:
Made with Eclipse Scout {0}.

Please see https://eclipsescout.github.io for documentation and other resources.
default.AccordionTextGroup:
This is the body of the current group. You can use any widget as body, in this case a LabelField is used.
Every group in an accordion is as height as its content.
default.AnchorBoundsTooltip: If set, the popup will use the given bounds as anchor. The format is: x,y,width,height
default.AppDescription:
Here you will find a demonstration of the Scout JS widgets. You can try them out and get a feel of how they are used. You should also try to adjust some properties and see what happens. Every widget comes with default settings but most of them are configurable to serve different purposes.

Every widget page is structured the same way: You will find the widget itself on top of the page. On the bottom is the configuration area where you can adjust the properties, execute actions or listen for events.

In fact this application is not only supposed to show you the widgets but may also serve you as API reference. You can see what is possible and how the widgets are used.

All the code is available on GitHub.

You should also check out the documentation about Scout JS in the technical guide.

Have fun!
default.AppWelcome: Welcome to the Scout JS Widgets Application
default.ApplyBookmarkToSearchFailedMessage: This bookmark is not applicable on the current search.
default.AskToSaveChangesOnCancel: Ask to save changes on cancel
default.AutoDateTooltip:
The auto date is the date which is preselected when the user clicks in an empty date field or presses the up or down key.
If the auto date is null, the current day is used instead.
default.AutoOptimizeColumnWidthsTooltip: If set on a column, the column will always be as width as its content. If not set, the user can still optimize the width manually by double clicking the separator between two columns.
default.AutoResizeColumnsTooltip: If set, the columns will take all the available width of the table. The configured width of the columns is used as weight for the width calculation and also as minimal width.
default.BlockFormatTooltip:
Using a formatter and parser you can adjust the text the user typed.
Try it by selecting this check box and entering a long string into the string field (like 12345678).
default.BookmarkActivationFailedOutlineNotAvaila: The bookmark cannot be activated because the outline '{0}' is not available.
default.BookmarkResetColumnFilters: The column filters have been removed during loading of the bookmark.

default.DefaultPasswordPolicyText:
The password does not comply with the given policy

Policy:
- at least 8 characters
- at least one number (0-9)
- at least one non standard character (!|@|#|\$|%|\^|&|\*|\(|\)|_|\+|\||~|-|
- not used in the past
- your username can't be a part of the password

default.DesktopDescription: The desktop is the main widget of a Scout application and the root of every other widget. The default desktop basically consists of a navigation, a header and a bench.
default.DropMaximumSizeTooltip: Maximum file size in bytes that is accepted when a file is dropped.
default.EventsDescription:
The following events are available for this widget:
{0}
default.EventsOverview:
Every widget can trigger events. Events are the result of actions, like clicking a button or deleting a row in a table. Changing a property will result in an event, too, a so called property change event.
You can listen for events by attaching an event handler. The event log below uses such an event handler and displays every triggered event for this widget. Try to interact with the widget or adjust some properties and see what happens.

Check out the technical guide for more details.
default.ExclusiveExpandTooltip: If checked, only one group may be expanded at the same time
default.ExternalWindowFieldText: The content has been opened in a new window. If no window has been opened or the window has been closed, it can be reopened.

default.GroupBoxScrollableTooltip:
If set, the group box will show vertical scrollbars when it is too small to display all the content. If the property is not set explicitly, only the main box will be scrollable by default.

When setting the property to true, remember to fix the height of the group box because the group box is by default as height as its content (useUiHeight is true).
default.HasCloseButtonTooltip: If the form has a close button, pressing the "x" icon will call close(), otherwise cancel() is called which will show a message if there are unsaved changes.
default.IOErrorInfo: Please check files and connection to server.
default.InheritAccessibilityTooltip:
Configures whether the widget inherits the enabled state of its parent widget.

For example a menu of a table field with inheritAccessibility = true is automatically disabled if the table field is disabled.
default.InternalProcessingErrorMsg: An internal processing error has occurred{0}.
default.LabelFieldValue: This is the value of a label field
default.LabelValue:
The purpose of this simple widget is to display text, either plain text or HTML text. HTML tags are encoded by default, so if you would like to display HTML content you need to set the property htmlEnabled to true. Try it out now to make the encoded tags in this text disappear.
A label is also able to display app links. App links create an event when clicked which you can listen for and execute an action. The following link is an app link: Click me

Please note: a label is not the same as a label field. A label field extends 'ValueField' and is a form field whereas the label is a simple widget. If you work with forms you should be using 'LabelField', if you work with plain widgets you can use a 'Label'.

default.LogicalGridTooltip:
The logical grid defines, how the fields are arranged inside the container.

The Horizontal Grid arranges them from left to right.
The Vertical Grid arranges them from top to bottom.
default.LogicalGridWithRefTooltip:
The logical grid defines, how the fields are arranged inside the container.

The Horizontal Grid arranges them from left to right.
The Vertical Grid arranges them from top to bottom.

See also the Logical Grid demo to get a feeling what the individual grid data properties mean.

If there is not even enough space to display the icon, it will be stacked into the ellipsis menu (if the property stackable is set to true).
default.MenuStackableTooltipText: If this property is set to true, the menu will be put into an ellipsis menu if there is not enough space to display it. You can try it out by making the browser window smaller.

default.RevealTooltip:
Brings the widget into view by scrolling the first scrollable parent. The action does not have any effect if the widget is already fully visible or there is no scrollbar. 

In order to test it make the window smaller so that the scrollbar appears, then scroll the widget out of view and press the button.

default.SpellCheckEnabledTooltip:
This flag requires the spell checker of the browser to be enabled (check browser settings).

Also, depending on your browser, changing the flag dynamically may not have an immediate effect. Try to adjust the text, leave the field (focus out) or rerender the field (navigate to another widget and come back) to force the browser to reapply the setting.
default.StatusMessage: This is a status with severity {0}
default.StringFieldHasActionMessage: If hasAction is true, the string field triggers an event called "action" when the icon is clicked.
default.Subject: Subject
default.TileGridVirtualTooltip:
Virtual relates to the term "Virtual Scrolling". This means, only the tiles in the view port and some more will be rendered. The others will be rendered as soon as they will be moved into the view port, either by scrolling or by any other action like sorting, filtering etc.

This can lead to a big performance boost when having many tiles, especially on Internet Explorer, but other browsers benefit as well.

To make Virtual Scrolling work, the real width and height needs to be known so that scroll bar position can be calculated correctly. This means Virtual Scrolling does only work if all tiles have the same size, so the following grid properties cannot be used: useUiWidth, useUiHeight, widthInPixel, heightInPixel, w, h, x, y.

If these preconditions are given, you can use the virtual mode and your grid will be able to handle a lot of tiles.
default.TileTypeTooltip:
The type of newly inserted tiles.

The content and visualization of a tile heavily depends on the use case. If you just want to display some data in a tile grid without the need of a custom styling and elaborated tile layout you can use a HtmlTile with the default display style.

If you want more control over the styling, just set a custom CSS class and add some rules. If you don't like the default rules you can also set the display style to PLAIN so that these default styles are not applied.

If you want even more control about the layout and content you can create a custom tile instead of using the HtmlTile as it is done here with CustomTile.js.

default.TrackLocationTooltipText:
If true, the location property is updated whenever the location of the iframe changes.

Note: This does only work if the iframe and the iframe's parent document have the same origin (protocol, port and host are the same).
